msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This compact Italian Book of Hours is illustrated with sixteen large miniatures facing the incipit pages of their respective sections, as well as two historiated initials. Its sequence of miniatures for the Hours of the Virgin diverges from the usual Infancy narrative. The book also contains a complete sequence of Passion miniatures for the Long and Short Hours of the Cross, as well as two miniatures for the Office of the Dead.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Rome
Modern collation and list of contents
Modern title page and list of miniatures
Hours of the Virgin, Use of Rome

supportDesc.extent: ii+244+iii; 99 x 72 mm bound to 108 x 79 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Mostly regular original catchwords in ink on versos at fols. 24v, 26v, 35v, 45v, 51v, 75v, 85v, 95v, 111v, 121v, 141v, 151v, 161v, 171v, 193v, 203v, 213v, 223v, 233v, 243v; recto side catchwords at 17r, 19r, 20r, 22r, 23r, 27r, 32r, 35r, 39r, 53r, 56r, 58r, 59r, 75r, 77r, 83r, 105r, 106r

layoutDesc.layout: One column of fourteen lines; written area: 55 x 42 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Sixteen large miniatures; two historiated initials; eighteen decorative initials; capitals alternately in red and blue; rubrication in red
14rModern photograph of a crucifixion, pasted in
44vLarge miniature, Meeting at the Golden Gate
158vLarge miniature, Crucifixion with Mary, John, and the two thieves
162vLarge miniature, Crucifixion with Mary and John
166vLarge miniature, Lamentation (Three Maries with the dead Christ)

binding.p: Italian eighteenth-century calf, gilt back, gilt cross on top cover, gilt edges with clasp, in red morocco case

origin.p: Saint Reparata appears in red in the calendar (8 October, fol. 11r) and Saints Reparata and Zenobius appear in the litany (fols. 121r and 120r); it is likely that the book was produced for Florentine use; early 15th century

history.provenance: Sir Thomas David Gibson Carmichael; sold by Sotheby's, London, March 23, 1903, no. 818; to Ellis and Elvey (Cat. 102, 1903, no. 225; Cat. 105, 1904, no. 50; Cat. 114, 1907, no. 8; Cat. 129, 1910, no. 413); (directly to?) John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
